Description: Sherwin Williams Company has agreed to pay a $570,000 civil penalty to settle alleged violations of hazardous waste regulations at its paint manufacturing facility located at 2325 Hollins Ferry Road in Baltimore, Md., the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/70042eb3dc8fe8568525792d00540bf4.html
Taken from the Federal Railroad Administration's FY2000 safety penalty report obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. A copy is available upon request.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The U.S. Department of Labor reached a settlement with the Cleveland-based Sherwin-Williams Co. providing $80 million to current and past participants of its Employee Stock Purchase and Savings Plan. The agreement was the result of an investigation by the Employee Benefits Security Administration into whether Sherwin-Williams, seeking to take advantage of tax breaks, improperly managed the plan in violation of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act.
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/ebsa/ebsa20130221-0
https://ai.fmcsa.dot.gov/SafetyProgram/spRptEnforcement.aspx?rpt=CLOSE

Description: The Sherwin-Williams Co., ConAgra and NL Industries agreed to pay a total of $305 million in settlement of allegations by the counties of Santa Clara, Alameda, Los Angeles, Monterey, San Mateo, Solano, and Ventura; the City and County of San Francisco; and the Cities of Oakland and San Diego, that they manufactured paint products containing lead when its danger to public health was known.
Info Source: https://www.oaklandcityattorney.org/News/Press%20releases/Lead%20Paint%20Settlement%20JULY%202019.html
